articles.headline: WNYC to Open New Podcast Division
articles.snippet: The unit is to open this week with a plan to raise $15 million for new programming, including a “New Yorker Radio Hour.”
articles.abstract: The unit is to open this week with a plan to raise $15 million for new programming, including a “New Yorker Radio Hour.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WNYC, the public radio powerhouse in New York, is about to grow even bigger through a new division that will develop programs for the expanding podcast market.

articles.headline: Oil Sands Boom Dries Up in Alberta, Taking Thousands of Jobs With It
articles.snippet: After extraordinary growth that attracted energy companies and billions in investments, the industry is in a state of financial strife, and navigating the decline has proved challenging.
articles.abstract: After extraordinary growth that attracted energy companies and billions in investments, the industry is in a state of financial strife, and navigating the decline has proved challenging.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT McMURRAY, Alberta — At a camp for oil workers here, a collection of 16 three-story buildings that once housed 2,000 workers sits empty. A parking lot at a neighboring camp is now dotted with abandoned cars. With oil prices falling precipitously, capital-intensive projects rooted in the heavy crude mined from Alberta’s oil sands are losing money, contributing to the loss of about 35,000 energy industry jobs across the province.

articles.headline: For-Profit Colleges Accused of Fraud Still Receive U.S. Funds
articles.snippet: The industry has been excoriated for preying on the poor, veterans and minorities, charging exorbitant fees for degrees that mostly don’t deliver promised jobs and skills.
articles.abstract: The industry has been excoriated for preying on the poor, veterans and minorities, charging exorbitant fees for degrees that mostly don’t deliver promised jobs and skills.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Obama administration agreed this summer to erase the federal loan debt of some former students at Corinthian Colleges, a for-profit school that filed for bankruptcy in the face of charges of widespread fraud, education officials promised to “protect students from abusive colleges and safeguard the interests of taxpayers.”

articles.headline: Latest Unease on Right: Ryan Is Too Far Left
articles.snippet: Some influential members of the conservative news media have turned on Representative Paul Ryan, whom Republicans are trying to draft for speaker of the House.
articles.abstract: Some influential members of the conservative news media have turned on Representative Paul Ryan, whom Republicans are trying to draft for speaker of the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Far-right media figures, relatively small in number but potent in their influence, have embarked on a furious Internet expedition to cover Representative Paul D. Ryan in political silt.

articles.headline: Nudes Are Old News at Playboy
articles.snippet: With the digital cornucopia of pornography, Playboy’s raison d’être has vanished. Its website dropped nudity last year and soon its magazine will still feature women, but not fully nude.
articles.abstract: With the digital cornucopia of pornography, Playboy’s raison d’être has vanished. Its website dropped nudity last year and soon its magazine will still feature women, but not fully nude.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, Cory Jones, a top editor at Playboy, went to see its founder Hugh Hefner at the Playboy Mansion.

articles.headline: In a Flurry of Deals, the Beginning of the End?
articles.snippet: Mergers and acquisitions are on track for a record year, with nearly $3.5 trillion worth of transactions. And that may signal the beginning of the end of a bull market.
articles.abstract: Mergers and acquisitions are on track for a record year, with nearly $3.5 trillion worth of transactions. And that may signal the beginning of the end of a bull market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first day of Wall Street’s workweek normally comes with the announcement of a corporate merger or two, hence the nickname “Merger Monday.” But these days, a more appropriate moniker might be “Manic Monday.”

articles.headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller to Join
articles.snippet: The deal, if completed, would combine the world’s two largest brewers, creating a behemoth that has annual revenue of $64 billion that commands 30 percent of global beer sales.
articles.abstract: The deal, if completed, would combine the world’s two largest brewers, creating a behemoth that has annual revenue of $64 billion that commands 30 percent of global beer sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: The king of beers is sizing up an even bigger crown.
articles.byline: By Chad Bray and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Afghan ISIS Branch Makes Inroads in Battle Against Taliban
articles.snippet: Islamic State victories against the Taliban have not weakened the overall insurgency, but have mostly inflicted more chaos and misery upon Afghan civilians.
articles.abstract: Islamic State victories against the Taliban have not weakened the overall insurgency, but have mostly inflicted more chaos and misery upon Afghan civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: SORKHROAD, Afghanistan — At least three times a week, Malaika hikes up the mountain, past mulberry and pine trees, to a clearing where she can get cellphone reception. She calls her family to reassure them that the Islamic State fighters have not come for her yet.
